awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a MALDI-TOF Mass Spectrometer to Advance Research and Undergraduate Research Training
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Colgate University is acquiring a matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF) mass spectrometer to support Professor George Geier and colleagues Ernest Nolen, Jacob Goldberg and Jennifer Peeler. In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species in complex samples. MALDI TOF combines gentle ionization (ideal for producing intact ions of peptides, proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, synthetic polymers, and other similarly sized species) with a detection mode that offers an excellent balance between sensitivity and accuracy across a wide mass range. This highly sensitive technique allows identification and determination of the structure of molecules in a complex mixture. The acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at the university and regional area. The instrument broadens participation by involving diverse students with this modern analytical technique. It is also used by collaborators at Hamilton College.

The award of the MALDI-TOF mass spectrometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It is especially useful to determine masses of synthetic glycopeptide mimics and their synthetic intermediates and for the development of chemical probes tethered to short peptides to detect zinc(II) ions in the nervous system.  The instrumentation is also used for monitoring the progress of peptide synthesis reactions, as well as for identifying products obtained via high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC)-based separations emanating from synthetic ventures. The instrument also serves researchers assessing expression of human selenoproteins via genetic code expansion, and carrying out assays of selenoprotein enzymatic activity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The funded project supported the acquisition of a Matrix Assisted Laser Desorption and Ionization Time-of-Flight mass spectrometer (MALDI-TOF MS) with enhanced resolution providing accurate mass determination, MS/MS capability, and a  proprietary TLC adapter allowing direct analyses from conventional aluminum backed TLC plates. The instrument has supported the research of four Colgate University faculty and their undergraduate students as well as two faculty and their students from nearby undergraduate-focused institutions.

Four broad research project areas at Colgate University have been positively impacted by the acquisition of the MALDI-TOF MS. (1) The MALDI-TOF MS has been used to characterize synthetic porphyrinoids and related compounds. Additionally, a collaborative study with a Bruker applications scientist found that porphyrinoids are excellent analytes for matrix-free, TLC-MALDI analysis. (2) MALDI-TOF MS data have been essential for the characterization of synthetic intermediates in the synthesis of glycosyl amino acid mimics of O-GalNAc-Ser by observing their sodium adducts. First, screening chromatography fractions for product and byproduct isolation has streamlined the workload. Second, mass spectral data has been vital for identifying unexpected byproducts and thereby guiding rational modification of experimental conditions. (3) Acquisition of the instrument enabled several advances in the field of biochemistry. For example, new methods were discovered to modify protein structures by attaching small molecules to cysteine residues with high efficiency and selectivity, a key objective for the development of antibody-drug conjugates used to treat certain forms of cancer. In separate work, the instrument was used in the preparation of new tools to visualize the release of zinc ions in the brain during neurotransmission. (4) The instrument has facilitated efforts to understand the functional role of the element selenium in protein function. The MALDI-TOF MS instrument has allowed accurate determination of the mass of proteins of interest, thereby indicating whether these proteins have been modified as a result of experimental manipulations and/or protein activity.

Key findings from research projects enabled by the MALDI-TOF MS have been disseminated at a national meeting of the American Society of Mass Spectrometry, national meetings of the American Chemical Society, and in publications in Bioconjugate Chemistry and the Journal of the American Chemical Society.

Additionally, the instrument has provided significant training opportunities to undergraduate students. Research students have learned to prepare samples, acquire, and process MALDI data independently. The instrument is featured in two 300-level laboratory courses, furthering the reach of this state-of-the-art instrument in the education and training of chemistry and biochemistry undergraduate students. Faculty have also benefited from professional development opportunities as a result of this project including training with TLC-MALDI imaging, automated analysis, collecting intact protein mass spectra, MS/MS analysis, and MS/MS data analysis for proteomics, database searching, and routines for analyzing incorporation of custom amino acids and post translational modifications.

 


Last Modified: 09/27/2024
Modified by: George R Geier
